Situation1: A violent assault is taking place in a public area, with bystanders in danger
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story:
I had been looking forward to this day for months. The temple was alive with color and music, the air thick with incense and the sound of prayers. As a Hindu, this festival was sacred to me—a time to reconnect with my faith, my family, and my community. I had traveled hours to be here, determined to take part in every ritual, every offering, just as my parents and grandparents had done before me.

But as I stood in line for the main ceremony, my phone buzzed urgently. There was a violent assault happening just a few blocks away, in a crowded market. As a police officer, I knew what was expected of me: to protect citizens, to act quickly, to put myself between danger and the innocent. My heart pounded as I looked at the faces around me—my family, my fellow devotees, all waiting for the blessings we had come so far to receive.

I felt torn in two. Duty to my badge pulled me one way, duty to my faith the other. The chanting grew louder, but inside me, a storm raged, and I didn’t know which call I would answer.
